First of all, what is a "laboratory accident"? So many people conflate "laboratory accident" with genetic engineering. The virus could have been released as a result of research activities at any point from sample collection to actual research to waste disposal. If a research worker in the field got Covid by walking into a bat cave to collect bats with insufficient PPE, or when obtaining virus samples from bats outside a bat cave with insufficient PPE or precautions, would either of those be a laboratory accident? Zoonoses and research accidents are not mutually exclusive events, and the concept of "laboratory accident" is vague and poorly defined and is used by very many people to mean many different things. But suppose we say that a laboratory accident means that a sample of the virus was in a laboratory and was released from that laboratory by accident, regardless of whether it was being stored or studied intentionally or whether its presence was incidental to some other work. How would we know whether the virus was released as a result of an accident? We'd know it was released in a lab accident if 1) someone finds a sample of it in a freezer, or 2) the intelligence community finds communications or data showing that someone had it in their freezer (and the only way they'd know that is if they had sequenced it). (Many early sequences were not released publicly, and many early patient samples were ordered destroyed; China was and is not eager to explore this possibility.) A variety of other information would offer supporting evidence, such as if any lab personnel had positive antibody test results very early on (supposedly they didn't, but those tests aren't perfect). There is no "smoking gun" signature of genetic engineering. Furin cleavage sites occur naturally. Moreover, if gain-of-function work was occurring, it would have been done at at least BSL3 if not BSL4, and I would expect that they would know what they are doing. Researchers who work at BSL3 and BSL4 are serious about what they do; accidents do happen but are uncommon. I think the most likely lab accident scenario would be from work characterizing bat coronavirus samples at BSL2, ironically most likely with the goal of understanding and mitigating their pandemic potential. It is also more plausible that BSL2 work could have been done sloppily or that there could have been a mistake. It would be much easier for a high-risk pathogen (that should be handled at BSL4) to escape BSL2 than BSL3 or BSL4. And we know that thousands of bat coronavirus samples were being studied at BSL2 at 2 institutes in Wuhan. So for me, this question really boils down to 2 other questions: 1) Does or will the intelligence community have evidence (communications, copies of lab notebook entries, sequence data, other data sets, etc.) that SARS-CoV-2 was present in a lab in Wuhan? 2) If so, would they release that information in the form of an assessment that a lab accident is a more probable scenario? I have no idea what the answer to 1) is. I'm in the very good company of many well-respected scientists who think that Covid could potentially have been released as a result of a lab accident. From my point of view, an accident related to sample collection is perhaps as plausible as a zoonotic origin unrelated to research, because the researchers live in a megacity, and that gives any zoonosis in a researcher a much better chance of spreading forward to new hosts. Moreover, the researchers purposefully interacted with countless bats. But who knows what information the intelligence community has. (And also, zoonosis during sample collection wouldn't count for this question.) Answering my question 2), I would think that if they had conclusive proof that the virus leaked out of a lab in Wuhan, that we would probably already have known about it. I'm not sure we would hear about anything short of conclusive proof, though, because it would sour relations with China in a way that devolves into "he said, she said" and doesn't offer clear benefit to the US. So, to summarize: it's possible that SARS-CoV-2 became pandemic as a result of a lab leak. I suspect that if the IC had conclusive proof that it was, then we'd know by now. If they don't, then I suspect we wouldn't hear much about whatever information they do have, and I don't think we'd hear for many years what would amount to an inflammatory claim (whether true or false) that a lab accident is a more probable scenario. PS A number of people here take as evidence for the lab leak hypothesis that China tried to cover up the virus' spread initially, or that they locked down forcefully. I believe that China tried to cover up its spread for much the same reason that local party officials tried to cover up events at Chernobyl: they didn't want to have to admit there was a problem. (And they were also not unique in the world in not wanting to acknowledge that there's a problem.) That doesn't say anything to me about the origin of the problem. As for locking down forcefully, it could just as well be argued that they waited too long and should have tamped its spread starting weeks earlier. I would argue that they locked down forcefully because of lessons learned from SARS. Indeed, following some initial missteps, China shared a remarkable amount of data quickly and addressed the virus' spread quickly, vastly more openly and quickly than after SARS. Moreover, whether one agrees or disagrees with their methods, they proved that Covid spread could be stopped. This had never been done before with any potentially pandemic virus that was this contagious. (SARS could have been pandemic but was far less transmissible.)
